text.front:
Who to Boost When for COVID-19 • OFID • 1
Open Forum Infectious Diseases
M A J O R A R T I C L E
Who to Boost When: The Effect of Age and Dosing Interval
on Delta and Omicron COVID-19 Incidence in the
Open-label Phase of the COVE Trial
Dean Follmann, 1, Xiaowei Wang, 2 Lindsey R. Baden, 3 Hana M. El Sahly, 4, Brandon Essink, 5 Peter Gilbert, 6 Holly E. Janes, 6 Colleen F. Kelley, 7,
Megan A. Berman, 8 Ian Frank, 9 Eric Chu, 1 Weiping Deng, 2 Frances Priddy, 2, Avika Dixit, 2 Joanne E. Tomassini, 2, Rituparna Das, 2 Jacqueline Miller, 2
and Honghong Zhou 2
1
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Biostatistics Research Branch, Bethesda, Maryland, USA, 2 Moderna, Inc., Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 3 Brigham and Women's Hospital,
Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, USA, 4 Departments of Molecular Virology and Microbiology and Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas, USA, 5 Meridian Clinical
Research, Savannah, Georgia, USA, 6 Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, Vaccine and Infectious Diseases Division, Seattle, Washington, USA, 7 Division of Infectious Diseases, Emory University
School of Medicine Grady Health System, Atlanta, Georgia, USA, 8 Department of Internal Medicine, University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, Texas, USA, and 9 Deparment of Infectious
Diseases, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA
Background. To help inform COVID-19 vaccination recommendations, we evaluated the impact of age and dosing interval on
clinical benefit of a third dose of mRNA-1273.
Methods. Approximately 17 000 participants from the phase 3 Coronavirus Efficacy trial who previously received 2 doses of
100 µg mRNA-1273 were evaluated for COVID-19 between September 2021 and April 2022 during uptake of a third booster
dose of 50 µg of mRNA-1273. Cox models assessed booster relative efficacy of a third dose.
Results. Initial booster relative efficacy against Delta COVID-19 was 83% (95% confidence interval, 60-93) 14 days postdose
and 83% (67-91) 60 days later. Initial booster efficacy against Omicron COVID-19 was 56% (44-65) at 14 days postdose and 4%
(-27 to 28) 120 days later. For those aged ≥65 years, initial booster efficacy against Omicron COVID-19 was 86% (69-93) compared
with 50% (36-61) for those <65 years. Placebo crossover to 2 doses of mRNA-1273 induced a median 5-month difference from the
second to third dose between the original randomized arms. Postboost, the mRNA-1273 arm had a 24% (16%, 32%) lower risk of
Omicron COVID-19 compared to the placebo-mRNA-1273 arm. Modeling predicted a 41% postboost reduction in Omicron
COVID-19 for a 15-versus 7-month interval between the second and third doses.
Conclusions. Boosting reduced Delta COVID-19 risk by 83% through 2 months and reduced Omicron COVID-19 risk by 56% but
declined by 4 months. A 15-versus 7-month dosing interval predicted a 41% postboost reduction in Omicron COVID-19 but increased
preboost risk.
Primary Funding Source. The National Institutes of Health/National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
Registration for the COVE Trial. ClinicalTrials.gov ID# NCT04470427
Keywords. COVID-19 vaccine; booster dose; SARS-CoV2; mRNA-1273.
Received 20 June 2024; editorial decision 13 November 2024; accepted 22 November 2024;
published online 25 November 2024
Correspondence: Dean Follmann, PhD, Biostatistics Research Branch, 5601 Fishers Lane,
Bethesda, MD 20892 (dfollmann@niaid.nih.gov).
Open Forum Infectious Diseases ®
Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of Infectious Diseases Society of America 2024.
This work is written by (a) US Government employee(s) and is in the public domain in the US.
https://doi.org/10.1093/ofid/ofae689
text.body:
With the emergence of new variants, SARS-CoV-2, COVID-19
remains a major threat to public health. Boosting the immune
response with additional vaccine doses increases antibody
levels [1-3] and reduces the risk of COVID-19 [4, 5]. As of
September 2024, the Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention (CDC) has tailored recommendations for vaccina-
tion depending on age, immunosuppression, and other factors.
For previously vaccinated adults, it is recommended to receive
a booster dose at least 6 months after their primary series or last
booster dose. The CDC notes that vaccination is especially
important for people at highest risk of severe COVID-19, in-
cluding people aged 65 years and older and other high-risk
groups [6]. As COVID-19 vaccine recommendations continue
to be updated, data to better understand additional dose dura-
bility, dosing intervals, and effectiveness in subgroups would be
helpful.
Studies showed that a fourth dose of mRNA-1273 adminis-
tered with a median dosing interval of around 180 days reduces
the risk of hospitalization and death by about 67% in those
aged >50 years [7]. A study with a test-negative design evaluated
the effectiveness of a third dose on hospitalization from Delta and
Omicron SARS-CoV-2 variants and found that for those aged
18-64 years vaccine, effectiveness was 82% and dropped to
54% by 15 weeks overall, and for those ≥65 years of age, the
analogous estimates were 92% and 77% [8]. A study of the mono-
valent XBB.1.5 over the 2023-24 season estimated vaccine
effectiveness (VE) against COVID-19 was 51% (95% confidence
text.note: Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/11/12/ofae689/7908454 by guest on 10 September 2025
text.body:
interval [CI], 47-54) during the first 7-59 days after an updated
dose and 39% (95% CI, 33-45) during the 60-119 days after an
updated dose. VE estimates against COVID-19-associated
hospitalization from 2 CDC VE networks were 52% (95% CI,
47-57) and 43% (95% CI, 27-56), with a median interval
from updated dose of 42 and 47 days, respectively [9].
The interval between vaccine doses is a modifiable factor that
can impact VE and immunogenicity. For many vaccines, a longer
interval between the first and second doses results in better prim-
ing and higher antibody levels postdose 2 [10]. For example, an
interval of 6-14 weeks between the first and second dose was
shown to induce higher neutralizing antibody (nAb) levels com-
pared to a 3-4 week interval for the BNT162b2 COVID-19 vac-
cine [11]. Currently, the CDC recommends that a subsequent
dose be received at least 6 months after the last dose, whereas
the World Health Organization suggests a minimum interval of
6-12 months depending on age and risk [12]. In practice, uptake
of additional doses has been much less than for the primary se-
ries, the intervals between doses vary widely, and the impact of
interval times on vaccine effectiveness has not been well studied.
The Coronavirus Efficacy (COVE) phase 3 trial (ClinicalTrials.
gov ID# NCT04470427) randomized approximately 30 000 par-
ticipants to 2 doses of 100 µg mRNA-1273 (Spikevax) or placebo
and demonstrated high efficacy against COVID-19 in December
2020 [13]. Subsequently, participants randomized to placebo
were offered mRNA-1273 primary series in December 2020
through April 2021. Following US government recommenda-
tions, a third dose of the original vaccine (booster) was offered
to trial participants starting 23 September 2021 [14]. This timing
created a difference in the interval between the second and third
dose of mRNA-1273 in the 2 groups (referred to here as the
mRNA-1273 arm and placebo/mRNA-1273 arm). The long-term
safety, immunogenicity, and efficacy of mRNA-1273 in the
COVE trial is reported in Baden et al [15]. In this study, we focus
on the efficacy and durability of a third dose of mRNA-1273
against the incidence of COVID-19 caused by Delta and
Omicron variants over the period September 2021-April 2022.
We use the same surveillance and endpoint as in the primary
publications [13, 16]. The modulatory effects of the interval be-
tween the second and third doses and age (those aged ≥65 vs
< 65 years) are investigated.
METHODS
Study Design and Population
Details of the COVE trial are presented elsewhere [13, 16].
Figure 1 provides a schematic of the analysis dataset used in
this study. COVE participants who received both doses of the pri-
mary immunization series of mRNA-1273 without major proto-
col violations and no evidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection as of
September 2021 comprise the analysis dataset. Participants who
acquired COVID-19 during the interval from the booster dose
up to 13 days later were censored. COVID-19 incidence was cal-
culated starting at 14 days postboost. Boosting was initiated on
September 2021 and participants who remained unboosted by
January 2022, were censored on that date. The incidence of Delta
and Omicron COVID-19 was assessed during the follow-up pe-
riod from 23 September 2021 to 5 April 2022 with COVID-19 de-
fined as a least 2 symptoms plus a positive real-time polymerase
chain reaction test using active surveillance where participants
were directed to be tested once they perceived symptoms (see
Supplementary Materials) [13, 15, 16]. Whole genomic sequenc-
ing was performed in SARS-CoV-2 polymerase chain reaction-
positive nasopharyngeal samples to identify infecting strain
[15]. A total of 8884 participants in the mRNA-1273 and
in the placebo/mRNA-1273 arms were evaluated in this open
label follow-up of the COVE trial.
In addition, a stratified random sample of the booster cohort
(n = 87 placebo/mRNA-1273 arm, n = 76 mRNA-1273 arm)
had nAb and binding antibody against ancestral and BA.1
Figure 1. Schematic of the Coronavirus Efficacy trial from July 2020 through April 2022. PDV is the participant decision visit where participants were unblinded.
Blue syringes denote mRNA-1273.
text.note:
• OFID • Follmann et al
Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/11/12/ofae689/7908454 by guest on 10 September 2025
text.body:
Omicron strain measured on the day of the boost (BD1) and 28
days later (BD29). We compared booster cohort for nAb and
binding antibody against ancestral and BA.1 Omicron strains.
See Supplementary Materials for details.
Statistical Methods. Cox proportional hazards regression models
with calendar time index were used to estimate booster relative ef-
ficacy and relative risk against incidence of Delta and BA.1
Omicron COVID-19 [17, 18]. The modulatory effects of age,
arm, and interval between second dose and booster were assessed.
Models included terms for sex, stratification factors for severe
COVID-19 risk (aged ≥18 years and aged <65 years with low
risk, aged ≥18 years and aged <65 years with higher risk, and
aged ≥65 years), a standardized risk score [13, 19], and an indica-
tor for unblinding before the median unblinding date. Models fit
separately for aged <65 years and aged ≥65 years removed the
stratification factors and adjusted for low/high risk in those aged
<65 years old. COVID-19 cases with missing SARS-CoV-2 strain
information had strain (Delta or Omicron) imputed by a Bernoulli
draw (coin flip) with probability of Delta given by the GISAID es-
timated proportion of Delta cases matched on date and state of the
COVID-19 case with missing strain information. The percent
reduction in COVID-19 over a year under different boosting
strategies was based on parameter estimates from a Cox model
with bootstrap CIs. Geometric means and ratios for the binding
and neutralizing antibodies were calculated using weights to
reflect the stratified sampling. Details are provided in the
Supplementary Materials.
Analyses were conducted in SAS version 9.4 and R version
4.1.1.
RESULTS
Booster Efficacy and Durability
Booster uptake was rapid with 60% of participants vaccinated
by 31 October 2021, 88% by 30 November 2021, and 97% by
31 December 2021 (Supplementary Figure 1). Baseline charac-
teristics of the early boosted and late/never boosted groups
were generally balanced (Table 1). The mean age (range) of
the analysis set was 52 (18-95) years, 48% of participants
were female and 82% were White. Modest imbalances included
higher numbers of participants in the early boosted group than
in the late/never boosted group who were aged ≥65 years,
White, of non-Hispanic ethnicity, and randomized to the
mRNA-1273 arm and unblinded early (ie, before the median
unblinded date) tending to boost early.
Supplementary Figure 2 presents the occurrences of adjudicat-
ed COVID-19 cases in the COVE trial from September 2021
through April 2022 annotated by booster status and strain.
Overall, there were 198 Delta COVID-19 cases and 1634
Omicron COVID-19 cases. Through the Delta period, 23
September 2021 through 15 December 2021, the total person
months of follow-up was 27 108 for the boosted and 26 405 un-
boosted groups. During the Omicron BA.1 period, 16 December
2021 through 5 April 2022, the analogous follow-up in person-
months was 59 486 for those boosted and 2283 unboosted, and
more than 95% of the Omicron cases were BA.1.

boosting, or were unboosted on 31 January 2022, and censored.
text.note: Who to Boost When for COVID-19 • OFID •
Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/11/12/ofae689/7908454 by guest on 10 September 2025
text.body:
For Delta COVID-19, an initial booster efficacy (95% CI) of
83% (60-93) was maintained at 83% (67-91) through 60 days
(Figure 2). For Omicron COVID-19, the initial booster efficacy
was 56% (44-65) and decreased to 38% (28-47) by 60 days and
4% (-27% to 28%) by 120 days. Figure 3 presents booster effi-
cacy separately for those aged ≥65 and <65 years for Omicron
COVID-19. The analogous estimates for those aged ≥65 years
were 86% (69-93) at 60 days and 28% (-47% to 65%) at 120
days, whereas those <65 years of age were 50% (36-61) and
6% (-29% to 31%), respectively. Preboost risk was similar for
the 2 age groups with the <65 years of age: ≥65 years of age haz-
ard ratio 0.98 (0.61-1.57).
Effect of Interval Between Second and Third Dose
Our next set of analyses contrasted the original randomized arms.
Supplementary Table 1 provides baseline characteristics of the
mRNA-1273 and placebo/mRNA-1273 arms, which were mostly
similar except for earlier unblinding in the placebo arm. A discus-
sion of the comparability of these pseudo-randomized groups is
given in the Supplementary Materials. The median (interquartile
range) months from second dose to booster was 12.9 (12.3, 13.5)
for the original vaccine arm and 8.2 (7.8, 8.7) for the crossover
placebo arm (Supplementary Figure 3).
We estimated the hazard ratio for the mRNA-1273 arm rela-
tive to the placebo/mRNA-1273 arm for the prebooster and post-
booster periods, Supplementary Table 2. Prebooster, the hazard
ratios (95% CIs) were 1.24 (0.91-1.70) and 0.91 (0.69-1.22) for
Delta and Omicron infection, respectively. As both CIs included
1, the efficacy from the primary immunization had decreased to a
similar level for both variants. Postbooster, the hazard ratios were
0.86 (0.44, 1.67) for Delta and 0.76 (0.68, 0.84) for Omicron infec-
tions. For Omicron, this corresponded to a 24% (16%, 32%) re-
duction in risk for the mRNA-1273 arm.
We also analyzed the effect of different intervals between the
second and third dose. A boost interval of ≥1 year was estimat-
ed to have a 28% (20%, 35%) reduction in risk compared to an
interval of <1 year. Treating month as a continuous variable, a
6% (4%, 8%) lower postbooster Omicron COVID-19 risk per
month increase in interval was estimated. Supplementary
Figure 4 shows the relative risk reduction, for intervals from
7 to 15 months compared to a 7-month interval. The postboos-
ter Omicron COVID-19 risk for a participant who remained
infection free and received the booster at 15 months was about
41% (30%, 50%) lower compared to a similar participant who
received the booster at the 7-month interval. In sensitivity anal-
yses, we adjusted for additional factors including health care
worker status, race, and ethnicity with minimal impact on the
model estimates.
Figure 2. Booster efficacy against Delta and Omicron COVID-19 over time.
Triangles represent the time of cases on the x-axis with random placement on
y-axis. Symbols at day 0 denote COVID-19 cases for participants who remained
unboosted throughout the trial.
Figure 3. Booster efficacy against Omicron COVID-19 over time by age group.
Triangles represent the time of cases on the x-axis with random placement on
y-axis. Symbols at day 0 denote COVID-19 cases for participants who remained
unboosted throughout the trial.
Table 2. Percent Reduction in COVID-19 Over 1 Year Following Boost on
1 October for Different age Groups, Constant or Winter Only Circulation of
SARS-CoV-2, and 8-or 14-month Intervals Between Booster Doses

text.note:
• OFID • Follmann et al
Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/11/12/ofae689/7908454 by guest on 10 September 2025
text.body:
Evaluation of Boosting Interval Strategies
To quantify the effect of different boosting intervals on
COVID-19 risk throughout a year, we used the estimated mod-
els to evaluate an 8-versus 14-month interval between doses on
the risk of COVID-19 relative to no boosting (Table 2). Our year
started on 1 October when both interval groups were boosted,
and their previous boost was either 8 or 14 months prior. The
8-month interval group received an additional dose on 1 May,
whereas the 14-month interval group was not dosed again.
Attack rates were either constant over the entire year or entirely
restricted to winter. For those aged <65 years, the benefit of
boosting was a 10%-20% reduction in COVID-19 risk relative
to no boosting, except for the 14-month interval group under
the Only Winter scenario for SARS-CoV-2 circulation. Under
this scenario, boosting was timed in October, a month before
the winter surge and was associated with a 36% reduction. For
those aged ≥65 years, the analogous estimates are 30%-40% re-
ductions with a 61% reduction for the 14-month interval timed
just before the winter surge.
Antibody Measurements pre-and Postbooster
The distribution of neutralizing antibodies and binding antibod-
ies against ancestral SARS-COV-2 (D614G) and BA.1 Omicron
strains at the day of boost (BD1) and 28 days (BD29) postboost
in the analysis set are shown in Supplementary Figures 5-S8. The
mRNA-1273 50-µg booster increased neutralizing antibody geo-
metric mean titers (GMTs) from baseline at BD1 with geometric
mean ratios (GMRs) (95% CIs) for placebo-mRNA-1237:
mRNA-1273 GMTs of 2.08 (1.45-2.97) and 1.12 (0.88-1.42)
for ancestral SARS-COV-2 (D614G) and Omicron BA.1 nAbs,
respectively (Supplementary Table 3). At BD29, the analogous
GMRs were 0.74 (0.55-1.00) and 0.70 (0.51-0.95). Findings for
binding antibodies were similar. Among participants aged <65
years, GMTs were higher than those aged <65 years at BD1
with GMRs of 1.86 (1.29-2.68) and 1.70 (1.39-2.09) for ancestral
SARS-COV-2 (D614G) D614G and Omicron BA.1 nAbs, re-
spectively (Supplementary Table 4). At BD29, the analogous
GMRs were 0.90 (0.65-1.25) and 0.86 (0.61-1.21). Results
were similar for binding antibodies.
DISCUSSION
Our study demonstrated that a third dose (50 µg) of the original
monovalent mRNA-1273 provided additional protection
against COVID-19 during the duration of the Delta wave in
the study, with an initial 83% reduction in Delta COVID-19,
which was maintained through 2 months of follow-up. It also
reduced the risk of Omicron, primarily BA.1, a more divergent
variant, providing an initial 56% reduction in Omicron
COVID-19, which dissipated by 4 months.
We separately studied those aged ≥65 years of age because of a
greater risk of death from COVID-19 in this population [20] and
found the effect of an additional dose was more pronounced
in those aged ≥65 years, with an initial efficacy in Omicron
COVID-19 of 86% compared to 50% for those aged <65 years.
In the blinded phase of COVE, there was no appreciable difference
in primary series vaccine efficacy by age against COVID-19, but
some unblinded studies showed similar or somewhat larger ben-
efit of vaccination/boosting for those aged ≥65 years and other
studies did not [16]. For example, in the VISION network, a study
estimated the vaccine effectiveness of booster doses of mRNA vac-
cines during the Delta and Omicron waves [21]. For the Omicron
period, the study found vaccine efficacy against hospitalization fol-
lowing a third dose within 2 months was 77% for those aged ≥65
years and 64% for those aged 18-44 years. Although we adjusted
for age, risk, and early unblinding, unmeasured confounding
may partly explain the greater benefit in those aged ≥65 years,
for example if those aged ≥65 years who boost early are also those
who especially avoid exposure. It is also possible that the vaccine
waned more in those aged ≥65 years, thus allowing a greater ben-
efit of the boost. The smaller benefit observed in younger persons
in our study provides a rationale for a risk-based approach for ad-
ditional doses, with emphasis on vaccinating those aged 65 and
older and other groups at higher risk of infection, such as immu-
nocompromised persons. A risk-based approach for the 2023-
2024 COVID-19 vaccination effort was adopted in the United
Kingdom and European Union, and current World Health
Organization recommendations for booster dose are do not in-
clude those aged younger than 50 years [12]. The cost effectiveness
of risk-based versus population-based approaches warrant addi-
tional careful evaluation [22-25].
We also saw a moderate but highly statistically significant
24% reduction in Omicron COVID-19 for those randomized
to the original vaccine arm (median interval of 13 months
between second and third dose) [26] compared to the
placebo-crossover arm (median interval of 8 months between
second and third dose) and modeling predicted a 41% reduc-
tion in post-boost COVID-19 for a 15-month interval com-
pared to a 7-month interval. Other studies of interval in the
primary series have been reported. For the ChAdOx-1-S
COVID-19 vaccine, if the interval between the 1st and 2nd
dose was at least 12 weeks of protection against ancestral
COVID-19 was estimated at 81% compared to an estimated
55% when the interval was less than 6 weeks [27]. A longer
interval was also associated with higher binding and neutraliz-
ing antibody levels against the ancestral and Omicron BA.1
strains. However, the interval between the second dose and
third doses had no appreciable impact on the incidence of
Delta COVID-19 [28]. This differential could be explained by
the higher infectivity of the Omicron strains, and its immuno-
logic distance from the ancestral strain. Studies showed that
after 3 doses of BNT162b2, the neutralizing antibody titers
were approximately 3-fold lower for the Delta strain versus
text.note: Who to Boost When for COVID-19 • OFID •
Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/ofid/article/11/12/ofae689/7908454 by guest on 10 September 2025
text.body:
16-fold lower for the Omicron strain, in comparison to ances-
tral strain [29].
To quantify the entire effect of a longer boosting interval
with higher preboost risk but lower postboost risk, we used
our estimated models to evaluate a strategy of 8-versus
14-month intervals. Other intervals would be of interest but in-
volve extrapolation beyond our data. We found modest benefits
of boosting in those aged <65 years and greater benefits for
those aged ≥65 years, except when boosting was fortuitously
timed to occur just before a winter surge with 36% and 61% re-
ductions in the 2 age groups, respectively. These results indicate
that if one can roughly time the boost before the surge, a longer
interval would be preferred but otherwise either interval pro-
vides similar benefits.
We also examined the impact of dosing interval on antibody
response by comparing the randomized arms. Consistent with
a shorter interval from second to third dose, antibody levels at
BD1 were higher in the placebo-mRNA-1273 arm and lower in
the mRNA-1273 arm with GMRs of 2.08 and 1.12 for ancestral
SARS-COV-2 (D614G) and Omicron BA.1 nAbs, respectively.
At BD29, the analogous GMRs were 0.74 and 0.70, respectively.
Longer dosing intervals improve antibody response for differ-
ent vaccines, and our study adds to this literature [10].
Our study has several limitations. We assessed boosting efficacy
of the original monovalent mRNA-1273 vaccine. The efficacy of
the current monovalent formula of mRNA-1273 vaccine remains
to be determined. In addition, the boosting efficacy was evaluated
against the Delta and BA.1 Omicron variants and not against var-
iants currently in circulation. The time of boosting was not ran-
domized and did not cover intervals shorter than 7 months.
Our analysis was performed in SARS-CoV-2-naïve individuals;
small numbers precluded an analysis of those with prior infection.
However, mRNA-1273 50 µg has been shown to be effective as a
booster regardless of prior infection status [15, 30]. And last, cases
were largely mild to moderate in severity, and an effect of the
interval on vaccine efficacy against severe disease cannot be
inferred from these data. A strength of the study was the
pseudo-randomized comparison of dosing interval by arm,
though dropout and infection may have resulted in group imbal-
ances in unmeasured confounders. Although we statistically ad-
justed for measured potential confounders and conducted
sensitivity analyses, residual unmeasured confounders are
possible.
In conclusion, these data demonstrate a clinical benefit of
additional mRNA-1273 vaccination for SARS-CoV-2-naïve
adults against mild to moderate Delta and BA.1 Omicron
COVID-19 with an increased benefit in those aged ≥65 years.
Additionally, although the research suggests there was a
benefit of a longer dosing interval between the primary
COVID-19 vaccination and booster dose, the clinical impact
of a longer interval is complex. A longer interval may have
led to a reduction in Omicron COVID-19, but this is
countered by an increased risk of COVID-19 while remaining
unboosted. Our modeling suggests similar benefits of 8-or
14-month interval unless one times a boost just before a surge,
in which case a longer interval has greater benefit. Although
updated research is needed on the impact of age and timing
of additional boosters on the efficacy of variant-targeting
vaccines, these data could be used to inform vaccination
policies [31].
text.div:
Supplementary Data
Supplementary materials are available at Open Forum Infectious Diseases
online. Consisting of data provided by the authors to benefit the reader, the
posted materials are not copyedited and are the sole responsibility of the
authors, so questions or comments should be addressed to the correspond-
ing author.
Notes

Acknowledgments. This is an analysis of the open-label phase of the
COVE trial and provides a more focused evaluation of the effect of boosting
than is presented in Baden et al [15]. Statistical modeling is more thorough-
ly developed with sensitivity analyses, the effect of interval is modeled, risk
by age evaluated, new antibody data is presented and the entire effect of dif-
ferent boosting intervals modeled.

Disclaimer. The findings and conclusions herein are those of the authors
and do not necessarily represent the views of the Department of Health and
Human Services or its components.

Data Sharing. Requests to use the data can be made to Moderna Inc., 200
Technology Square, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA. A materials transfer and/
or data access agreement with the sponsor will be required for accessing of
shared data.

IRB Approval. The COVE trial was conducted in accordance with
the Good Clinical Practice guidelines of the International Council
Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human
Use, and applicable government regulations. The central institutional review
board approved the protocol and the consent forms. All participants provided
written informed consent.

Financial support. This work was supported in whole or in part with fede-
ral funds from the Department of Health and Human Services;
Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response; Biomedical
Advanced Research and Development Authority, under Contract No.
75A50120C00034 (Moderna, Inc.). This study was supported by the
National Institutes of Health. The content is solely the responsibility of the
authors and does not necessarily represent the official views of the National
Institutes of Health.

Potential conflicts of interest. All authors have completed the ICMJE
uniform disclosure form at www.icmje.org/coi_disclosure.pdf.
